Introduction

Vasospastic angina (formerly variant or Prinzmetal angina) is characterized by intermittent coronary vasospasm, resulting in transient myocardial ischemia and angina.  It most commonly affects relatively young patients (age <50) with minimal risk factors for atherosclerotic coronary artery disease (CAD); however, smoking is a strong risk factor, likely by contributing to endothelial dysfunction.  Recognizing vasospastic angina is important for reducing symptoms and preventing serious complications.

Pathophysiology



Vasospastic angina likely results from a combination of endothelial dysfunction and autonomic imbalance.  The major underlying defect is likely a deficiency of vasodilatory nitric oxide in the coronary artery endothelium, which causes the acetylcholine released from vagus nerve terminals to trigger vasoconstriction rather than vasodilation (

figure 1
).  Hyperreactivity of intimal smooth muscle in the coronary arterial wall can lead to focal or diffuse epicardial coronary vasospasm, resulting in transient myocardial ischemia and angina.

Risk factors



  • Smoking is one of the strongest risk factors for vasospastic angina.
  • Cocaine use may increase the risk.
  • The incidence is likely similar in men and women.
  • Other disorders of vascular dysfunction, including migraine headaches and Raynaud phenomenon, may have an association with vasospastic angina, but this has not been clearly demonstrated.

Clinical presentation



Patients with vasospastic angina typically have the following presenting features:



  • Recurrent episodes of chest discomfort that resolve spontaneously within 15 minutes.
  • Episodes that are often accompanied by diaphoresis, nausea, palpitations, and/or dyspnea.
  • Episodes that usually occur at rest or during sleep (when vagal tone is high).
  • Episodes that are occasionally induced by hyperventilation, exercise, or stress.
  • Symptoms that characteristically improve with nitrate administration.

Physical examination



Physical examination during a chest pain episode is largely unremarkable, other than moderate general distress.  Like other ischemic cardiac pain, the pain of vasospastic angina is not reproducible on palpation of the chest.

ECG



Baseline ECG is typically unremarkable.  During an episode of chest pain, ECG commonly demonstrates ST-segment elevation in contiguous leads corresponding with the vasospastic artery, similar to ST-segment elevation myocardial infarction (

image 1
).

Laboratory



Because of the short duration of ischemia, serum troponin levels are usually normal in patients with vasospastic angina.  High-sensitivity troponin levels may occasionally be elevated.

Diagnosis



The diagnosis of vasospastic angina should be suspected based on clinical presentation and is confirmed via the following testing:

Ambulatory ECG monitoring



Ambulatory ECG monitoring (eg, an event monitor) may be used to demonstrate ST-segment elevation or other ischemic changes during an episode of chest pain, confirming that the chest pain is due to myocardial ischemia.

Ruling out atherosclerotic CAD



Cardiac stress testing (

) or coronary angiography (CT scanâ€“based or invasive) is performed to rule out atherosclerotic CAD as the cause of anginal pain (ie, no evidence of obstructive atherosclerotic CAD).  When invasive coronary angiography is performed, acetylcholine provocation testing can be performed to confirm vasospastic angina (
figure 2
):  Dysfunctional coronary endothelium responds paradoxically to acetylcholine (which is normally a vasodilator) with vasoconstriction.

Differential diagnosis

Atherosclerotic CAD



Atherosclerotic CAD can cause stable angina with chest pain characteristics similar to those of vasospastic angina; however, stable angina reliably occurs with exertion and resolves with rest.  Cardiac stress testing and/or coronary angiography can be used to evaluate whether angina symptoms are atherosclerotic CAD.  Some patients may have symptoms related to both vasospastic angina and atherosclerotic CAD.

Coronary microvascular ischemia



Coronary microvascular ischemia involves dysfunction and vasospasm of the small coronary arterioles rather than the epicardial coronary arteries.  It typically presents with stable angina symptoms in patients with multiple risk factors for atherosclerosis (eg, diabetes mellitus, hyperlipidemia) and is more common in women.  During invasive coronary angiography, acetylcholine provocation testing can help differentiate vasospastic angina from microvascular ischemia.

Stress-induced cardiomyopathy



Stress-induced cardiomyopathy (takotsubo cardiomyopathy) can present with chest pain similar that of vasospastic angina.  Postmenopausal women with a recent physical or emotional stressor are most commonly affected.  In stress-induced cardiomyopathy, ECG usually does not reveal ST-segment elevation during an episode of chest pain.

Diffuse esophageal spasm



Diffuse esophageal spasm can cause intermittent substernal chest pain that improves with nitrates; however, it may be accompanied by dysphagia and is not typically associated with ST-segment changes on ECG.

Management

Smoking cessation



Immediate smoking cessation is first-line therapy for active smokers who develop vasospastic angina because cessation substantially decreases the frequency of chest pain episodes.

Pharmacologic therapy



Initial therapy includes the following:



  • Sublingual nitroglycerin is taken as needed as an abortive agent when symptoms occur.
  • A calcium channel blocker (CCB) is taken regularly to inhibit coronary artery vasoconstriction and prevent anginal episodes:
    • Amlodipine or diltiazem is preferred first-line therapy.
    • Short-acting nifedipine should be avoided due to a short half-life that can create rebound symptoms.


For patients with persistent symptoms, the following medications can be added:



  • A long-acting nitrate (eg, isosorbide mononitrate) can assist in symptom prevention when added to a CCB.
  • A statin (eg, fluvastatin) may help reduce symptoms when added to a CCB, perhaps due to beneficial effects on vascular smooth muscle.


Medications that can encourage vasospasm and should be avoided include:



  • Beta blockers without alpha blocking effects (eg, metoprolol, propranolol):  These drugs may encourage coronary vasoconstriction by facilitating unopposed alpha-1 receptor stimulation by endogenous catecholamines.
  • Triptans (eg, sumatriptan) and ergot alkaloids (eg, ergotamine):  These drugs can induce coronary vasoconstriction via stimulation of 5-HT1B and 5-HT1D serotonin receptors.  Normally, the vasoconstriction is somewhat offset by the endothelial release of vasodilatory prostaglandins, but this response is lacking in affected patients due to endothelial dysfunction.
  • Cholinergic agents (eg, bethanechol, carbachol):  Although normally used as vasodilators, cholinergic agents have a paradoxical vasoconstrictive effect on dysfunctional coronary endothelium.

Complications

Myocardial infarction



Vasospastic angina can occasionally cause prolonged vasoconstriction or can induce coronary artery thrombus that leads to myocardial infarction.  Minimizing vasospastic episodes helps reduce the risk for myocardial infarction.

Ischemia-induced arrhythmia



Vasospastic angina causing sustained ischemia can trigger serious arrhythmias, including ventricular tachycardia and ventricular fibrillation.

Sudden cardiac arrest



The risk for sudden cardiac arrest (SCA) due to ischemia-induced ventricular arrhythmia is increased in patients with untreated vasospastic angina.

Prognosis



The prognosis in patients with vasospastic angina is generally favorable because symptoms are usually manageable with therapy.  However, mortality is substantially increased without appropriate treatment, with up to 25% of patients experiencing serious complications (ie, myocardial infarction, serious arrhythmia), including a significant risk for SCA.  These data highlight the importance of diagnostic recognition and appropriate treatment.

Summary



Vasospastic angina (
